climbs.name: Undertaker
climbs.fa: Prep: Dave McRae, solo.  FFA Dave McRae and Tyler Tanhoff 9/2017

content.description:
Undertaker burls through several overhangs, and like everything else at the Overlook, it's steeper than it looks.  Minor ledge fall potential and spaced bolting make this a good route to not fall on.

 P1. Start at a boulder problem through an overhanging fist crack (.10+), after a shake at a ledge, step right and power past sloping melons on a steep, rounded arete. 9 bolts, 5.11a, 90 feet.

 P2. Navigate one bulge after another while mostly avoiding OW moves in the six inch crack. 8 bolts, 5.10+, 90 feet.

 Descent: If lowering from the second pitch anchor, make sure to clip a leash/draw to the belay end of the rope to pull back to the belay ledge rather than be stuck hanging in space. Or, top out and belay off the tree and scramble off.
content.protection: All bolts with stainless steel 'biners on the anchors.
content.location: Located on the North facing, downhill side of Steins Overlook. Undertaker is the second route right of a huge chimney/cave feature, and starts at an overhanging fist crack protected by a single bolt.

climbs.name: Sideshow Bob
climbs.fa: Prep: Dave McRae, solo  FFA: Dave McRae & Lael Smith 8/21/2018

content.description: 25 feet of junk leads to the funnest 25 feet of climbing at Steins Overlook. Hand traverse the overhanging rail for the classic 5.10d version. Foot traverse the rail and skip the rightmost bolt for the lesser, 5.10b version, Side Out.
content.location: Located on the North facing, downhill side of Steins Overlook.  Look for the prominent traversing rail to the left of a small cave and right of Honeybee.

content.description: The best route at Steins Overlook contains continuously steep and solid rock through three distinct sections: 5.10 steep jugs, 5.12 bouldery moves, then a 5.11 pumpy finish. A proud tick!
content.location: The Shining is on the uphill side of the Overlook, and easily viewed from the main trail.

content.description:
P1. The all-bolted, 90 foot, first pitch works techy corner moves to a steep finish. 5.10d P2. The signature second pitch ascends a very steep hand to fist crack through a "petrified" white streak. 5.10b

 Descent: If lowering from the second pitch anchor, make sure to clip a leash/draw to the belay end of the rope to pull back to the belay ledge rather than be stuck hanging in space. Or, top out and belay off the tree and scramble off.
content.protection: P1. 10 bolts to anchor with steel 'biners   P2. 2 bolts and enough #1 to #4 camalots for a 100 foot pitch (doubles or triples). No stoppers or small cams. Bolted anchor with steel 'biners.
content.location: Petrified is on the north facing, downhill side of Steins Overlook.  It starts immediately left of a large chimney/cave feature.

content.description: A fun, slightly overhanging, bolted jug haul on the East face of Steins Overlook.
content.protection: 6 bolts and anchors with stainless steel 'biners
content.location: East face of Steins Overlook. Honeybee and Friday the 13th are the first routes encountered when descending cross country from the main trail.

climbs.name: Friday the 13th
climbs.fa: Dave McRae and Michael Faith.  April 2018

content.description: Friday the 13th features bouldery moves, a cryptic crux, and a persistent coating of lichen on the non-essential holds.  It shares the finishing moves and anchor with Honeybee.  Despite the name, it's well protected and safe.
content.protection: 6 bolts to an anchor with steel 'biners.
content.location: The farthest uphill route on the east face of Steins Overlook.  It climbs through a black streak to the left of Honeybee.

climbs.name: Frankensteens
climbs.fa: Prep: Dave McRae, solo  FFA: Dave McRae & Liz Elhoffer 6/24/2018

content.location: Prominent arete on the North facing, downhill side of Steins Overlook.  Located right of a huge chimney/ cave feature.

climbs.name: Close Encounters
climbs.fa: Prep: Dave McRae, solo  FFA: Dave McRae & Tyler Tanhoff 7/6/2018

content.description: Close Encounters shares the first 20 feet with Undertaker, then goes straight up the face and inside corner.  The "Close Encounter" comes near the top when it forces an up close and personal interaction with an intimidating overhang.   With the correct cryptic sequence, it feels easy for the grade.  Until that's deciphered, it feels nearly impossible.  For full value, climb the bolted off-width second pitch of Undertaker.
content.location: Located on the right side of the North facing, downhill side of Steins Overlook.  It starts at an overhanging fist crack protected by a single bolt.

content.description:
Steins Overlook is a formation adjacent to Steins Pillar that overhangs on nearly all aspects. It contains two climbs up to two hundred feet tall on the nearly perma-shaded north aspect, as well as a couple single pitch sport routes.

 With the exception of The Shining, routes on Steins Overlook were developed through extensive trundling. The rock removal from each route could be measured in tons.  This crag is not for everyone.  Expect kitty litter and loose rock. Wear a helmet!

 All grades are currently tentative as the routes await repeats. Please feel free to leave feedback on grades and they will be adjusted once a consensus is reached.
